definitions.text: yielding readily to pressure or weight
compassionate and kind; conciliatory
examples: he was soft on his children

definitions.text: (of sound) relatively low in volume
easily hurt
produced with vibration of the vocal cords
examples: voiced consonants such as `b' and `g' and `z'

definitions.text: not protected against attack (especially by nuclear weapons)
used chiefly as a direction or description in music
examples: the piano passages in the composition

definitions.text: (of light) transmitted from a broad light source or reflected
(of speech sounds); produced with the back of the tongue raised toward the hard palate; characterized by a hissing or hushing sound (as `s' and `sh')
(of a commodity or market or currency) falling or likely to fall in value
examples: the market for computers is soft

definitions.text: using evidence not readily amenable to experimental verification or refutation
tolerant or lenient
examples: indulgent parents risk spoiling their children

definitions.text: soft and mild; not harsh or stern or severe
having little impact
examples: an easy pat on the shoulder
a soft (or light) tapping at the window

definitions.text: out of condition; not strong or robust; incapable of exertion or endurance
examples: he was too soft for the army

definitions.text: willing to negotiate and compromise
not burdensome or demanding; borne or done easily and without hardship
examples: the easygoing life of a parttime consultant

definitions.text: mild and pleasant
examples: the climate was mild and conducive to life or growth

definitions.text: not brilliant or glaring
in a relaxed manner; or without hardship;  (`soft' is nonstandard)
examples: just wanted to take it easy
